title: Mini-Project: Contact Manager System
objectives: Apply all dictionary and set concepts in a real-world project
Build a complete contact management system
Practice data validation and user interaction
Combine dictionaries, sets, and comprehensions effectively

sections.title: The Concept
sections.content:
ğŸ“‡ Building a Contact Manager

Real-World Application:

A contact manager is like a digital address book where you can:

  • ğŸ“ Store contact information (name, phone, email, tags)
  • ğŸ” Search for contacts by various criteria
  • ğŸ·ï¸ Tag contacts with categories (work, family, friends)
  • ğŸ“Š Analyze your contact database

This project combines everything you've learned about dictionaries and sets!

Skills You'll Practice:

  • âœ… Nested dictionaries (contact details)
  • âœ… Dictionary methods (.get(), .update(), etc.)
  • âœ… Sets (unique tags, email domains)
  • âœ… Comprehensions (filtering, transforming)
  • âœ… Data validation
  • âœ… Menu-driven program structure

sections.title: Syntax Breakdown
sections.content:
ğŸ” Key Patterns Used

1. Nested Dictionary Structure:

contacts = {
    "contact_id": {           # Outer dict: ID â†’ Contact
        "name": "...",        # Inner dict: field â†’ value
        "phone": "...",
        "email": "...",
        "tags": {...}         # Set of tags
    }
}

2. Safe Dictionary Access:

# Using .get() to avoid KeyError
contact = contacts.get(contact_id)
if contact:
    # Process contact
else:
    # Handle not found

3. Dictionary Comprehension for Filtering:

# Find all contacts with specific tag
work_contacts = {cid: contact for cid, contact in contacts.items() 
                 if tag in contact['tags']}

4. Set Operations on Tags:

# Add tags
contact['tags'].update(new_tags)

# Remove tags
contact['tags'].difference_update(old_tags)

# Find common tags
common = set1 & set2

5. Set Comprehension for Unique Values:

# Get all unique email domains
domains = {c['email'].split('@')[1] for c in contacts.values()}

sections.title: Exercise
sections.content:
âœï¸ Your Turn: Extend the Contact Manager

Challenge: Add new features to the contact manager.

Requirements:

  1. Add a function export_by_tag(tag) that returns a list of contact names with that tag, sorted alphabetically
  2. Add a function find_duplicates() that finds contacts with the same phone number or email
  3. Add a function merge_tags(old_tag, new_tag) that replaces all occurrences of old_tag with new_tag across all contacts
  4. Add a function get_contacts_without_tags() that returns contacts with no tags

def get_contacts_without_tags():
    """Return contacts that have no tags."""

    pass

# Test your functions
print("Testing new features...")

sections.explanation:
ğŸ“š How the Solutions Work:

  1. export_by_tag() - List Comprehension + Sorted:
    names = [contact['name'] for contact in contacts.values() 
         if tag in contact.get('tags', set())]
return sorted(names)
    • Filter contacts by tag membership
    • Extract just names
    • Sort alphabetically
  2. find_duplicates() - Grouping Pattern:
    • Build dict of phone â†’ list of contacts
    • Build dict of email â†’ list of contacts
    • Filter to only entries with 2+ contacts
  3. merge_tags() - Set Operations:
    contact['tags'].discard(old_tag)  # Remove old
contact['tags'].add(new_tag)      # Add new

sections.title: Key Takeaways
sections.content:
ğŸ¯ What You've Learned:

  1. Real-world data modeling:
    • Nested dictionaries for complex records
    • Sets for tags/categories
    • IDs as dictionary keys
  2. CRUD operations:
    • Create: add_contact()
    • Read: get_contact(), search functions
    • Update: update_contact()
    • Delete: delete_contact()
  3. Search and filter patterns:
    • Dictionary comprehensions for filtering
    • Set operations for tag logic
    • String matching for search
  4. Data analysis:
    • Counting with dictionaries
    • Aggregating with sets
    • Statistics generation

This project demonstrates:

  • âœ… How dictionaries model real-world entities
  • âœ… How sets handle unique collections (tags, domains)
  • âœ… How comprehensions simplify data processing
  • âœ… How to build a complete, functional application

ğŸš€ Module 7 Complete!

You've mastered Python's most powerful data structures! Ready for Module 8: Error Handling!

checkpoint_quiz.question: What data structure is best for storing unique tags for a contact?
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: A SET is best for tags because: (1) tags should be unique - no duplicates, (2) order doesn't matter, (3) fast membership testing for 'has this tag?'. Lists allow duplicates, dicts need key:value pairs, and tuples are immutable.

checkpoint_quiz.question: How would you find all contacts with a specific tag using dictionary comprehension?
options: {c for c in contacts if tag in c}
{cid: c for cid, c in contacts.items() if tag in c['tags']}
[c for c in contacts if tag in c['tags']]
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: Option B is correct: {cid: c for cid, c in contacts.items() if tag in c['tags']}. It creates a dict with contact IDs as keys, filters by checking if tag is in the contact's tags set, and uses .items() to get key-value pairs. Option A doesn't access tags, C creates a list not dict, D doesn't filter.

checkpoint_quiz.question: Why use .get() instead of direct access when retrieving contacts?
options: It prevents KeyError if contact doesn't exist
checkpoint_quiz.explanation: Use .get() to prevent KeyError when the contact ID doesn't exist. contacts[id] crashes if id isn't found, but contacts.get(id) returns None (or a default). This makes code more robust and easier to handle missing data gracefully.
